ccre.util

Class ExpirationTimer

  • java.lang.Object
    • ccre.util.ExpirationTimer

  • public class ExpirationTimer
extends java.lang.Object
    An ExpirationTimer acts sort of like an alarm clock. You can schedule a series of alarms with certain delays, and then start the timer. When each delay passes, the timer will trigger the event associated with the delay. The timer can be fed, which restarts the timer (can be used to implement WatchDogs, hence the name). The timer can also be stopped, which resets the timer and prevents it from running until it is started again.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      protected class  ExpirationTimer.Task
      A task that is scheduled for a specific delay after the timer starts.

    • Method Detail

      • schedule

        public void schedule(long delay,
            EventConsumer cnsm)
              throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Schedule an EventConsumer to be triggered at a specific delay.
        Parameters:
        delay - the delay (in milliseconds) to trigger at.
        cnsm - the event to fire.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer is already running.

      • schedule

        public EventSource schedule(long delay)
                     throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Return an event that will be triggered at the specified delay.
        Parameters:
        delay - the delay (in milliseconds) to trigger at.
        Returns:
        the event that will be fired.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer is already running.

      • start

        public void start()
           throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Start the timer running.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer was already running.

      • feed

        public void feed()
          throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Reset the timer. This will act as if the timer had just been started, in terms of which events are fired when.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer was not started.

      • stop

        public void stop()
          throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Stop the timer. This will prevent the timer from running until start is called again.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer was not started.

      • getStartEvent

        public EventConsumer getStartEvent()
        Get an event that, when fired, will start the timer. This will not throw an IllegalStateException if the timer is already running, although it will log a warning.
        Returns:
        the event to start the timer.

      • getFeedEvent

        public EventConsumer getFeedEvent()
        Get an event that, when fired, will feed the timer. This will not throw an IllegalStateException if the timer is not running, although it will log a warning.
        Returns:
        the event to feed the timer.

      • getStopEvent

        public EventConsumer getStopEvent()
        Get an event that, when fired, will stop the timer. This will not throw an IllegalStateException if the timer is not running, although it will log a warning.
        Returns:
        the event to stop the timer.

      • startWhen

        public void startWhen(EventSource src)
        When the specified event occurs, start the timer. See getStartEvent() for details.
        Parameters:
        src -
        See Also:
        getStartEvent()

      • feedWhen

        public void feedWhen(EventSource src)
        When the specified event occurs, feed the timer. See getFeedEvent() for details.
        Parameters:

        See Also:

      • stopWhen

        public void stopWhen(EventSource src)
        When the specified event occurs, stop the timer. See getStopEvent() for details.
        Parameters:
        src -
        See Also:
        getStopEvent()

      • getRunningControl

        public BooleanOutput getRunningControl()
        Get a BooleanOutput that can be written to in order to control whether or not this timer is running. This will start or stop the timer when the outputted value changes. This will not throw an IllegalStateException if the timer is in the wrong state or log a warning.
        Returns:
        a BooleanOutput to control the ExpirationTimer.
